event: Sigma-Aldrich (later to become part of Millipore Sigma) files patent application. Sigma was one of many parties to file a U.S. patent application for the use of CRISPR-Cas9 in eukaryotic cells.

Broad/Harvard/MIT/Rockefeller group files patent application. The Broad/Harvard/MIT/Rockefeller group was the fourth party to file a U.S. patent application for the use of CRISPR-Cas9 in eukaryotic cells.
Church lab publishes paper describing use of CRISPR-Cas9 in human cells
keywords: Church lab publishes paper describing use of CRISPR-Cas9 in human cells

event: Joung group at Massachusetts General Hospital publishes paper using CRISPR-Cas9 in zebrafish
Researchers find a repeat array in an archaeal conjugative plasmid.[13][3]

Russian scientist Alexander Bolotin, working at Institut national de la recherche agronomique, discovers an unusual CRISPR locus while studying the bacteria streptococcus thermophilus. Although similar to previously reported systems, the CRISPR array discovered would lack some of the known cas genes and instead contained novel cas genes, including one encoding a large protein they predicted to have nuclease activity, which is now known as Cas9. Bolotin's team would also note that the spacers, which have homology to viral genes, all share a common sequence at one end. This sequence would be later known as protospacer adjacent motif (PAM).[8][3]
keywords: "Bolotin", "Institut national de la recherche agronomique", "streptococcus thermophilus", "cas genes*", "Cas9", "protospacer adjacent motif", " PAM"

event: Scientists characterize type II Trans-activating crRNA (tracrRNA)–based processing mechanism.[3]
Jennifer Doudna and Emmanuelle Charpentier submit the first patent application for CRISPR-Cas 9 technology.[15]

Team led by Feng Zhang at the Broad Institute reports that it has used CRISPR to cut DNA in human cells, opening the door for the tool to be used in medicine.[23][24] In the same month, a number of other researchers at different laboratories publish papers within a few weeks of each other demonstrating how the CRISPR system could be used to edit genomes in human cells.[15]
Intellia Therapeutics is launched as a gene editing company, focusing on the development of therapeutics utilizing a the CRISPR/Cas9 system.[35]
Leading United Kingdom research organizations issue declare support of the continued use of CRISPR-Cas9 and other genome-editing techniques in preclinical research.[37]
Professor Jennifer Doudna gives a TED Talk about the bioethics of using CRISPR.[38]
The United Kingdom Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority (HFEA) autorizes researchers get green light to genetically modify human embryos.[44]

American magnate Bill Gates endorses the use of CRISPR technique to create malaria-resistant mosquitoes. By September, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation would plan to double the sum it was spending under the Gates–funded project Target malaria, to create a mosquito-killing technology that relies on CRISPR gene editing.[49][50][51]
keywords: "Bill Gates",  "malaria", "mosquitoes". "Bill and Melinda Gates( Foundation)*",  "Target malaria"

event: Researchers at the University of California, Berkeley, develop new version of the CRISPR-Cas9 gene-editing technology called CRISPR-Gold, a technology that uses gold nanoparticles for delivering the CRISPR/Cas9 gene-editing system to cells that, when tested in the mdx mouse model of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), repair the faulty DMD gene, leading to improved strength and agility and reduced fibrosis.[69][70][71][72][73]
papers: kunwo:2017; mumal:2017; israel:2017; laycock:2017; ktorri:2017; leitchi:2017

event: Discovery of CRISPR and its function: Francisco Mojica was the first researcher to characterize what is now called a CRISPR locus, reported in 1993.
actors: Francisco Mojica, University of Alicante, Spain

event: tracrRNA forms a duplex structure with crRNA in association with Cas9. Deltcheva et al. 2011.
In vitro characterization of DNA targeting by Cas9. Jinek et al. 2012. Gasiunas et al. 2012.
Researchers find CRISPR sequences in Escherichia coli, but do not characterize their function
Caribou Biosciences raises $11 Million. Focus: Research, industry, therapeutics, agriculture
CRISPR Therapeutics raises $89 Million. Focus: Therapeutics
The CRISPR mechanism first published. Amemura, Ishino, Makino, Nakata, Shinagawa, Takase, Wachi. Osaka University
actors: Amemura, Ishino, Makino, Nakata, Shinagawa, Takase, Wachi

event: CRISPR-Cas is used to edit the genome of a zebrafish
CRISPR-Cas used to engineer plant genomes including rice, wheat, Arabidopsis, tobacco and Sorghum
Hinxton Group issues a statement indicating that most of the ethical and moral questions raised about CRISPR and gene editing have been debated before
UK scientists sought license to genetically modify human embryos to study the role played by genes in the first few days of human fertilisation
UNESCO’s International Bioethic Committee called for ban on genetic editing of human germline
First CRISPR-Cas9 clinical trial launched
Chinese scientist convicted for using CRISPR-Cas9 in human babies

event: First patient received gene editing therapy with CRISPR directly administered into the body
